_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Minnesota Energy is committed to the protection of its employee, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substance used in the ethanol fuel production process.  It is the policy of Minnesota Energy to comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws. 

ORDER OF IMPORTANCE  
In any emergency situation the order of importance is as follows
1  People/Employees
2  Community/Environment
3  Property

EVACUATION STEPS
Step 1 Determine substance of leak and immediately put on mask and instruct the other two operators to do the same

Step 2 Analyze situations - take appropriate action ?Immediate Evacuation? or ?Shut down Evacuation?

Step 3 Assign an operator to notify truck drivers and office personnel to evacuate and rendezvous at assigned point and shut down natural gas line.
Evacuation Point   Cooling Tower
Alternate Point     Employee Parking Lot
Off Site Point        North Parking lot of bank on Main St

Step 4 If completing a ?Shut down Evacuation? begin to shut the plant down according to the shut down procedures listed below with the assistance of the other operator

Step 5 If not completing a ?Shut down Evacuation? or after completing the shutdown report immediately to rendezvous point along with operators

Additional emergency action plan documents are available for review in the offices of Minnesota Energy and are also on file with Buffalo Lake Fire Department and the Renville County Emergency Response Commission.

Facility Description and Regulated Substance Handled

Minnesota Energy operates and ethanol fuel production plant located near in Buffalo Lake, in Renville County, Minnesota.  The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn and the following by products: wet corn distillers, dry corn distillers, and corn distillers? soluble.   
The fuel ethanol production process requires use of the following RMP regulated substances:
Denaturant (natural gasoline) which is report

ed to contain 30 - 40 percent pentane.  The maximum amount of natural gasoline on-site is estimated to be 155,554 pounds.  The natural gasoline is stored in two tanks as a liquid and is introduced to the fuel ethanol in the final stage of production.  The natural gasoline is added to the ethanol to  make the ethanol unfit for human consumption.  The denaturant tank is located in the facility?s tank farm area which includes secondary containment
Ammonia (anhydrous) which 100% ammonia by volume.  The maximum ammonia stored on-site is estimated 18,000 pounds.  The ammonia is stored in two 9,000 pound bullets and is introduced into the system during the cook process for pH control.  The tanks are stored outdoors on the south side of the building with chocks in place to prevent the bullets from moving.  Empty tanks are replaced with full tanks by the vendor that provides the ammonia.
Chlorine Gas which contains 100% chlorine by volume.  The maximum chlorine stored on-site per process is estimated to be 4,000 pounds.  The chlorine is stored in 2,000 pound cylinders and is introduced into the system in the cooling water and the boiler water as a water treatment.  Two tanks are stored on the north-west side of property outside the cooling towers and the two tanks are stored on the south side of the facility next to the boiler room.  Empty cylinders are replaced with full cylinders by the vendor that provides the chlorine.

Off Site Consequence Analysis

In addition to identifying and reporting regulated materials at the Minnesota Energy facility, the US Environmental Protection Agency?s (EPA?s) Risk Management Plan (RMP) program guidance requires companies to share with their communities a look at the worst possible accident that could happen at a facility (as unlikely as that might be) and an alternative, more realistic accident scenario.

RMP*CompTM, a software tool developed by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric administration was used to perform an off-site conse

quence analysis the of the Minnesota Energy facility. 
The worst case scenario defined by RMP Guidance is a failure of any one of the storage tanks of the regulated chemicals.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, Minnesota Energy has complied with the EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68.  Process safety information and orientation/maintenance procedures are documented on-site.  Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis, training, change management and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis.  Audits of the overall RM will be conducted on regular basis to assure compliance with EPA regulations.


Five Year Accident History

Minnesota Energy has not had a spill of any of the regulated chemicals on-site that caused death, injuries, environmental of property damage, evacuation, or in place sheltering the last five years the fuel production facility.
